title: KYPO Cyber Range Training Platform - Demo Content
description: The demo contains all types of levels to demonstrate the training capabilities of the KYPO Cyber Range Platform.

levels.title: Info
levels.content:
# Demo Summary

The demo contains all types of levels to demonstrate the training capabilities of the KYPO Cyber Range Platform.

**Note**: It is recommended to use the Chrome browser. In case you run into difficulties with submitting the answer, try to Log out and Log in again. 

| Level | Level Name | Level Type |
|:------:|------| ------ |
| 1. | Info | Info |
| 2. | Finding Open Ports | Training |
| 3. | Connecting via Telnet | Training |
| 4. | Privilege Escalation | Training |
| 5. | Test Example | Assessment |
| 6. | Assessment Example | Assessment |

## Info

The level contains this information page.

## Finding open ports

The level provides information on how to connect to a sandbox. In general, there are two possible options. The first option is to use the platform'a GUI to connect to the machine via Spice console. The second option is to connect through SSH with a generated config file and keys.

This level's small challenge is to scan open ports.

## Connecting Via Telnet

This level's challenge is to connect to the server machine without a password and discover the secret answer.

## Privilege Escalation

This demo's bigger challenge is to gain root privileges and read an answer available only to a root user. Enjoy! 

## Test Example

The level contains a simple example of a test. Tests can be used, for example, for additional testing of students for grading purposes.

## Assessment Example

The level contains a simple example of a test. For example, the tests can be used to verify the learning outcomes or for collecting feedback.

levels.title: Finding open ports
levels.content:
Your goal is to get access to a **server**. You know that there is a **telnet** service running on the server but it is not running on the default port. Your first task is to find the **port** on which the telnet service is running. The answer is the port number.

Below are two options how to connect to the client from which you can connect to the server.

## GUI access
1. In the topology overview, click the button in the top-right corner of the graph, then **`Expand All`**, **`client`** and **`Generate console URL`**. After a few moments, **`Open link`** next to the **`Generate console URL`** should appear.

2. Login using username **`kypo`** and password **`kypo`**.

## SSH from local machine
1. Use the **`Get SSH Access`** button to download **`ssh-access.zip`**.

2. Extract the **`ssh-access.zip`** file to your **`~/.ssh/`** directory.

    `$ unzip ssh-access.zip -d ~/.ssh/`

3. Change the SSH private key permissions if needed.

    `$ chmod 600 ~/.ssh/pool-id-ID-sandbox-id-ID-user-key`

4. Connect to the client virtual machine specified in the SSH configuration.

    `$ ssh -F ~/.ssh/pool-id-ID-sandbox-id-ID-user-config client`
levels.solution:
1. Connect to the client using either of the options.

2. Look for open ports using the command **`nmap server`**. You can see **ssh** running on port **22** and some other service running on port **2323**. This has to be the **telnet** service.

3. Enter **`2323`** as the answer.

hints.title: Tool to find open ports
hints.content: A common tool to find open ports is **nmap**. You can learn how to use nmap using **`nmap --help`** or by searching online.

levels.title: Connecting via Telnet
levels.content: Now you have the port number and you would like to connect, but you don't have any credentials. Luckily you know that user **`alice`** has a weak password. You might be able to guess it. The answer is in alices home directory. There is a list of common passwords placed in your home directory for your convenience.
levels.solution:
1. You know that **alice** has a weak password so you can try a dictionary attack. A list of common passwords is ready in your home directory. One of possible tools to make a password attack is **hydra**. A command to find the password is **`hydra -l alice -P passlist.txt telnet://server:2323`**. This will reveal alices password **`bacon`**.

2. Now you can connect to the server by using **`telnet server 2323`**, entering username **`alice`** and her password **`bacon`**.

3. To read the answer you can use **`cat flag.txt`**. The answer is **`Top_Secret_Flag`**.

hints.title: Connecting using telnet
hints.content: The command to connect using telnet is **`telnet <host> <port>`**, so in our case **`telnet server 2323`**. You will be prompted to enter an username and password.

hints.title: Tool for password attacks
hints.content: Common tools for password attacks are **hydra** and **medusa**. Consult their help commands or man pages to find appropriate options to perform the attack. You can use the list of common passwords stored in your home directory. Use **`ls`** to list files.

levels.title: Privilege Escalation
levels.content:
Great, you managed to login to the server as **alice** but there is not much you can do as **alice**. Can you find a way to become **root**? The answer is in the root directory.

One of common privilege escalation attack vectors is badly configured **sudo**. To see what you can use sudo for, use the **`sudo --list`** command.
levels.solution:
1. You can see that the only command you can use sudo on is **`less /home/alice/flag.txt`**. There is not much to see in the flag, but you can run this as **root**. Is there a way to get a shell?

2. There is, all you have to do is enter **`!sh`** while running the **`sudo less /home/alice/flag.txt`** to get a root shell.

3. To get the answer, use **`cd`** to enter the root directory and **`cat flag.txt`** to read the answer. The answer is **`Cant_Guess_This`**.

hints.title: Using the privilege escalation
hints.content: You have probably figured out that you can run **sudo** on a certain **less** command. To get a shell run **`sudo less /home/alice/flag.txt`**, enter the password. Type **`!sh`** to get a root shell.

questions.text: What was the name of a file storing the answer?
The Telnet service was running on the default port.
Match services with their default port numbers.

levels.title: Assessment Example

questions.text: How did you connect to the client?
How would you improve this demo?

levels.instructions: Please answer the questions. The last question is voluntary.
